content: I read your remark on cochains only now. What's up with their associativity? How can they lose it if their ambient algebra has it? :thinking:
It's been a long time since I thought about the argument (like 20 years). :thinking:

Maybe it helps to go back to the universal derivations stuff?

Consider three vertices V={1,2,3}V = \{1,2,3\}V={1,2,3} with corresponding basis e1,e2,e3∈KVe^1,e^2, e^3\in K^Ve1,e2,e3∈KV together with a complete edge set
{}
E~={(1,1),(1,2),(1,3),(2,1),(2,2),(2,3),(3,1),(3,2),(3,3)}=V×V\tilde E = \{(1,1),(1,2),(1,3),(2,1),(2,2),(2,3),(3,1),(3,2),(3,3)\} = V\times VE~={(1,1),(1,2),(1,3),(2,1),(2,2),(2,3),(3,1),(3,2),(3,3)}=V×V
{}
with corresponding bases
{}
e1,1,e1,2,e1,3,e2,1,e2,2,e2,3,e3,1,e3,2,e3,3∈KE~.e^{1,1},e^{1,2},e^{1,3},e^{2,1},e^{2,2},e^{2,3},e^{3,1},e^{3,2},e^{3,3}\in K^{\tilde E}.e1,1,e1,2,e1,3,e2,1,e2,2,e2,3,e3,1,e3,2,e3,3∈KE~.
{}
The unit element is
{}
1=e1+e2+e31 = e^1+e^2+e^31=e1+e2+e3
{}
and the (complete) graph operator is
{}
G~=1⊗K1=∑(i,j)∈E~ei,j=e1,1+e1,2+e1,3+e2,1+e2,2+e2,3+e3,1+e3,2+e3,3.\tilde G = 1\otimes_K 1 = \sum_{(i,j)\in\tilde E} e^{i,j} = e^{1,1}+e^{1,2}+e^{1,3}+e^{2,1}+e^{2,2}+e^{2,3}+e^{3,1}+e^{3,2}+e^{3,3}.G~=1⊗K​1=∑(i,j)∈E~​ei,j=e1,1+e1,2+e1,3+e2,1+e2,2+e2,3+e3,1+e3,2+e3,3.

The universal derivation d~:A→Ω~\tilde d: A\to\tilde\Omegad~:A→Ω~ is given by
{}
d~f=∑(i,j)∈E~[f(j)−f(i)]ei,j.\begin{aligned}\tilde d f & = \sum_{(i,j)\in\tilde E} \left[f(j)-f(i)\right] e^{i,j}\end{aligned}.d~f​=(i,j)∈E~∑​[f(j)−f(i)]ei,j​.
Note that all terms involving a "loop" ei,ie^{i,i}ei,i vanish from the sum.

Also note that although G~\tilde GG~ is not an element of Ω~=ker(m)\tilde\Omega = \mathsf{ker}(m)Ω~=ker(m) (since it contains loops), G~\tilde GG~ generates Ω~\tilde\OmegaΩ~ via d~.\tilde d.d~. The loops vanish due to the commutator.

This is truly a universal derivation (proven in Bourbaki among other places) so any other derivation d:A→Ωd:A\to\Omegad:A→Ω factors through this one, i.e. for every ddd, there is a unique (up to isomorphism) ϕ:Ω~→Ω\phi:\tilde\Omega\to\Omegaϕ:Ω~→Ω given by
{}
ϕ(ei,j)=eidej\phi(e^{i,j}) = e^i d e^jϕ(ei,j)=eidej
{}
where i≠ji\ne ji=j such that
{}
d=ϕ∘d~d = \phi\circ\tilde dd=ϕ∘d~
{}
and vice versa. ϕ\phiϕ amount to basically setting some of the ei,j=0.e^{i,j} = 0.ei,j=0.

Back to this example, it means:
{}

  • d~e1=e2,1+e3,1−e1,2−e1,3\tilde d e^1 = e^{2,1}+e^{3,1}-e^{1,2}-e^{1,3}d~e1=e2,1+e3,1−e1,2−e1,3
  • d~e2=e1,2+e3,2−e2,1−e2,3\tilde d e^2 = e^{1,2}+e^{3,2}-e^{2,1}-e^{2,3}d~e2=e1,2+e3,2−e2,1−e2,3
  • d~e3=e1,3+e2,3−e3,1−e3,2\tilde d e^3 = e^{1,3}+e^{2,3}-e^{3,1}-e^{3,2}d~e3=e1,3+e2,3−e3,1−e3,2

{}
Adding the three expressions above demonstrates
{}
d~1=d~(e1+e2+e3)=0.\tilde d 1 = \tilde d (e^1+e^2+e^3) = 0.d~1=d~(e1+e2+e3)=0.

Multiplying on the left demonstrates:
{}
ei,j=eid~eje^{i,j} = e^i\tilde d e^jei,j=eid~ej
{}
for i≠ji\ne ji=j and Ω~\tilde\OmegaΩ~ is spanned by these guys (see Bourbaki) so a general element in Ω~\tilde\OmegaΩ~ can be expressed as
{}
α=∑(i,j)∈E~,i≠jα(i,j)ei,j\alpha = \sum_{(i,j)\in\tilde E, i\ne j} \alpha(i,j) e^{i,j}α=∑(i,j)∈E~,i=j​α(i,j)ei,j
{}
so you can kind of see why I go back on forth on whether I want to include loops in E~.\tilde E.E~. If I don't include loops, then I can just write
{}
α=∑(i,j)∈E~α(i,j)ei,j\alpha = \sum_{(i,j)\in\tilde E} \alpha(i,j) e^{i,j}α=∑(i,j)∈E~​α(i,j)ei,j
{}
but then I can't write G~=1⊗K1\tilde G = 1\otimes_K 1G~=1⊗K​1, which is kind of nice to be able to do. Either way is fine :shrug:
To see where nonassociativity comes in, I think we need to look at what is Ω~2.\tilde\Omega^2.Ω~2.

It is not too tricky to show that
{}

  • d~e1,2=e3,1,2−e1,3,2+e1,2,3\tilde d e^{1,2} = e^{3,1,2} - e^{1,3,2} + e^{1,2,3}d~e1,2=e3,1,2−e1,3,2+e1,2,3
  • d~e2,1=e3,2,1−e2,3,1+e2,1,3\tilde d e^{2,1} = e^{3,2,1} - e^{2,3,1} + e^{2,1,3}d~e2,1=e3,2,1−e2,3,1+e2,1,3
  • d~e2,3=e1,2,3−e2,1,3+e2,3,1\tilde d e^{2,3} = e^{1,2,3} - e^{2,1,3} + e^{2,3,1}d~e2,3=e1,2,3−e2,1,3+e2,3,1
  • d~e3,2=e1,3,2−e3,1,2+e3,2,1\tilde d e^{3,2} = e^{1,3,2} - e^{3,1,2} + e^{3,2,1}d~e3,2=e1,3,2−e3,1,2+e3,2,1
  • d~e3,1=e2,3,1−e3,2,1+e3,1,2\tilde d e^{3,1} = e^{2,3,1} - e^{3,2,1} + e^{3,1,2}d~e3,1=e2,3,1−e3,2,1+e3,1,2
  • d~e1,3=e2,1,3−e1,2,3+e1,3,2\tilde d e^{1,3} = e^{2,1,3} - e^{1,2,3} + e^{1,3,2}d~e1,3=e2,1,3−e1,2,3+e1,3,2

{}
which follows from the definition
{}
d~ei,j=d~(eid~ej)=(d~ei)(d~ej)=∑k∈V(ek,i,j−ei,k,j+ei,j,k)\begin{aligned}\tilde d e^{i,j} = \tilde d (e^i\tilde d e^j) = (\tilde d e^i)(\tilde d e^j) = \sum_{k\in V} (e^{k,i,j} - e^{i,k,j} + e^{i,j,k})\end{aligned}d~ei,j=d~(eid~ej)=(d~ei)(d~ej)=k∈V∑​(ek,i,j−ei,k,j+ei,j,k)​

On notation, recall that
{}
ei,j=ei⊗Kej,i≠je^{i,j} = e^i\otimes_K e^j,\quad i\ne jei,j=ei⊗K​ej,i=j
{}
are bases for Ω~.\tilde\Omega.Ω~.

It is tempting to let
{}
ei,j,k=ei⊗Kej⊗Kek,e^{i,j,k} = e^i\otimes_K e^j\otimes_K e^k,ei,j,k=ei⊗K​ej⊗K​ek,
{}
but it is better to think of these as
{}
ei,j,k=ei,j⊗Aej,k=(ei⊗Kej)⊗A(ej⊗Kek)∈Ω~⊗AΩ~,e^{i,j,k} = e^{i,j}\otimes_A e^{j,k} = (e^i\otimes_K e^j)\otimes_A (e^j\otimes_K e^k)\in\tilde\Omega\otimes_A\tilde\Omega,ei,j,k=ei,j⊗A​ej,k=(ei⊗K​ej)⊗A​(ej⊗K​ek)∈Ω~⊗A​Ω~,
{}
i.e. these are directed 2-paths (or secretly 2-simplices).

There is, however, an obvious map:
{}
Ω~⊗An→A⊗K(n+1)\tilde\Omega^{\otimes A n} \to A^{\otimes_K (n+1)}Ω~⊗An→A⊗K​(n+1)
{}
with
{}
ei,j,k=ei,j⊗Aej,k↦ei⊗Kej⊗Keke^{i,j,k} = e^{i,j}\otimes_A e^{j,k} \mapsto e^i\otimes_K e^j\otimes_K e^kei,j,k=ei,j⊗A​ej,k↦ei⊗K​ej⊗K​ek
{}
and I actually make use of this when I define diamonds.

Pausing for a second, what I've shown above (in gory tedious detail) is that the universal derivation
{}
d~:A→Ω~\tilde d:A\to\tilde\Omegad~:A→Ω~
{}
maps 000-paths to linear combinations of 111-paths. This can be extended to a derivation
{}
d~:Ω~→Ω~⊗AΩ~\tilde d:\tilde\Omega\to\tilde\Omega\otimes_A\tilde\Omegad~:Ω~→Ω~⊗A​Ω~
{}
that maps 111-paths to linear combinations of 222-paths.

As long as you are dealing with complete graphs / universal derivations, we have
{}
d~2=0,d~(f g)=(d~f) g+f (d~g).\tilde d^2 = 0,\quad \tilde d(f\, g) = (\tilde d f)\, g + f\,(\tilde d g).d~2=0,d~(fg)=(d~f)g+f(d~g).
(btw, I think everything I said in my last few comments are just an application of well know stuff to a simple complex involving 3 vertices)

I think the more traditional approach with simplices assumes a total order on vertices and keeps only the paths with the right order so that the universal
{}

  • d~e1=e2,1+e3,1−e1,2−e1,3\tilde d e^1 = e^{2,1}+e^{3,1}-e^{1,2}-e^{1,3}d~e1=e2,1+e3,1−e1,2−e1,3
  • d~e2=e1,2+e3,2−e2,1−e2,3\tilde d e^2 = e^{1,2}+e^{3,2}-e^{2,1}-e^{2,3}d~e2=e1,2+e3,2−e2,1−e2,3
  • d~e3=e1,3+e2,3−e3,1−e3,2\tilde d e^3 = e^{1,3}+e^{2,3}-e^{3,1}-e^{3,2}d~e3=e1,3+e2,3−e3,1−e3,2

{}
becomes
{}

  • de1=−e1,2−e1,3d e^1 = -e^{1,2}-e^{1,3}de1=−e1,2−e1,3
  • de2=+e1,2−e2,3d e^2 = +e^{1,2}-e^{2,3}de2=+e1,2−e2,3
  • de3=+e1,3+e2,3d e^3 = +e^{1,3}+e^{2,3}de3=+e1,3+e2,3

{}
i.e. ϕ(ei,j)=0\phi(e^{i,j}) = 0ϕ(ei,j)=0 if i>ji>ji>j so that Ω\OmegaΩ is spanned by e1,2,e2,3,e1,3∈Ωe^{1,2}, e^{2,3}, e^{1,3}\in\Omegae1,2,e2,3,e1,3∈Ω and the universal
{}

  • d~e1,2=e3,1,2−e1,3,2+e1,2,3\tilde d e^{1,2} = e^{3,1,2} - e^{1,3,2} + e^{1,2,3}d~e1,2=e3,1,2−e1,3,2+e1,2,3
  • d~e2,1=e3,2,1−e2,3,1+e2,1,3\tilde d e^{2,1} = e^{3,2,1} - e^{2,3,1} + e^{2,1,3}d~e2,1=e3,2,1−e2,3,1+e2,1,3
  • d~e2,3=e1,2,3−e2,1,3+e2,3,1\tilde d e^{2,3} = e^{1,2,3} - e^{2,1,3} + e^{2,3,1}d~e2,3=e1,2,3−e2,1,3+e2,3,1
  • d~e3,2=e1,3,2−e3,1,2+e3,2,1\tilde d e^{3,2} = e^{1,3,2} - e^{3,1,2} + e^{3,2,1}d~e3,2=e1,3,2−e3,1,2+e3,2,1
  • d~e3,1=e2,3,1−e3,2,1+e3,1,2\tilde d e^{3,1} = e^{2,3,1} - e^{3,2,1} + e^{3,1,2}d~e3,1=e2,3,1−e3,2,1+e3,1,2
  • d~e1,3=e2,1,3−e1,2,3+e1,3,2\tilde d e^{1,3} = e^{2,1,3} - e^{1,2,3} + e^{1,3,2}d~e1,3=e2,1,3−e1,2,3+e1,3,2

{}
becomes
{}

  • de1,2=e1,2,3d e^{1,2} = e^{1,2,3}de1,2=e1,2,3
  • de2,3=e1,2,3d e^{2,3} = e^{1,2,3}de2,3=e1,2,3
  • de1,3=−e1,2,3d e^{1,3} = -e^{1,2,3}de1,3=−e1,2,3

{}
so that Ω⊗AΩ\Omega\otimes_A\OmegaΩ⊗A​Ω is one dimensional and spanned by e1,2,3.e^{1,2,3}.e1,2,3.
You're right. I can't think of why it should be nonassociative. Proof by exhaustion :joy:

I haven't thought about the simplicial stuff since grad school, but it seems the total ordering can be given a physical interpretation as giving each nnn-simplex a kind of temporal direction so the first vertex can be thought of as an event that happens before the last vertex :thinking:
i.e. traversing an edge involves moving forward in time. This automatically rules out cycles, loops, etc.
This is a common property with diamonds so maybe totally ordered simplices and diamonds are not so different after all :thinking:

Maybe this is where non-associativity comes in...

Given α,β∈Ω\alpha,\beta\in\Omegaα,β∈Ω, what is α β∈Ω⊗AΩ\alpha\,\beta\in\Omega\otimes_A\Omegaαβ∈Ω⊗A​Ω?

The only thing I can think of that it could be is:
{}
α β=[(α(1,2) e1,2+α(2,3) e2,3+α(1,3) e1,3] [(β(1,2) e1,2+β(2,3) e2,3+β(1,3) e1,3]=α(1,2) β(2,3) e1,2,3.\begin{aligned} \alpha\,\beta &= \left[(\alpha(1,2)\,e^{1,2}+\alpha(2,3)\,e^{2,3}+\alpha(1,3)\,e^{1,3}\right]\,\left[(\beta(1,2)\,e^{1,2}+\beta(2,3)\,e^{2,3}+\beta(1,3)\,e^{1,3}\right] \\ &= \alpha(1,2)\,\beta(2,3)\,e^{1,2,3}.\end{aligned}αβ​=[(α(1,2)e1,2+α(2,3)e2,3+α(1,3)e1,3][(β(1,2)e1,2+β(2,3)e2,3+β(1,3)e1,3]=α(1,2)β(2,3)e1,2,3.​
{}
This product would be associative, but I think this might be antisymmetrized so that
{}
α∧β=[α(1,2) β(2,3)−β(1,2) α(2,3)] e1,2,3.\alpha\wedge\beta = \left[\alpha(1,2)\,\beta(2,3)-\beta(1,2)\,\alpha(2,3)\right]\,e^{1,2,3}.α∧β=[α(1,2)β(2,3)−β(1,2)α(2,3)]e1,2,3.
{}
This product, although looking more like the continuum wedge product, would not be associative :thinking:

The associative product of simplicial cochains
{}
α β=α(1,2) β(2,3) e1,2,3\alpha\,\beta = \alpha(1,2)\,\beta(2,3)\,e^{1,2,3}αβ=α(1,2)β(2,3)e1,2,3
{}
does not, in any obvious way that I can see, approximate wedge product.

However, if you put two simplicial 2-cochains together (forming a 2-diamond), you get
{}
α β=[α(1,2) β(2,3)−α(1,2′) β(2′,3)](e1,2,3−e1,2′,3).\begin{aligned}\alpha\,\beta = \left[\alpha(1,2)\,\beta(2,3)-\alpha(1,2')\,\beta(2',3)\right] (e^{1,2,3} - e^{1,2',3}).\end{aligned}αβ=[α(1,2)β(2,3)−α(1,2′)β(2′,3)](e1,2,3−e1,2′,3).​
{}
This is associative and approximates the continuum wedge product.
Diamonds for the win :blush: :large_blue_diamond:
Note: 1-diamonds are directed edges and 2-diamonds are "directed squares", but nnn-diamonds for n>2n>2n>2 are richer than just nnn-cubes (although directed nnn-cubes are nnn-diamonds).

Note^2: You cannot form a diamond with just 3 vertices. If there is not a fourth vertex present allowing you to construct a 2-diamond from 3 existing vertices, then the 2-simplex formed from the 3 vertices is equal to zero in discrete differential geometry.

i.e. the space of 2-diamonds Ω2\Omega^2Ω2 is spanned by pairs of 2-simplices sharing the same start and end vertex, e.g.
{}
ei,j,k−ei,j′,k.e^{i,j,k}-e^{i,j',k}.ei,j,k−ei,j′,k.

Wilson talks about this a bit (Wilson as in Sullivan-Wilson with a competing formulation to ours) in

  • DIFFERENTIAL FORMS, FLUIDS, AND FINITE MODELS
The product defined in this paper :point_of_information: is graded commutative and nonassociative.

On the bottom of page 4:

There is also a graded commutative nonassociative product on C∙C^\bulletC∙ described easily in terms of the elementary cochains a,ba,ba,b as follows
